TO WILLIAM WADE, ITS AUTHOR'S FREE-HEARTED BROTHER AND EVER-STEDFAST FRIEND OF-ALL-WEATHERS, THE FOLLOWING POEM, âPROTHANASIA,â IS AFFECTIONATELY INSCRIBED.

PROTHANASIA. The subject of this poem was suggested by the published correspondence of Bettine Brentano with Goethe and others. Several passages from one or two of her remarkable letters have been adopted, in a modified shape, in the second part of the poem: but, for the main portions of that part; for the entire first and third parts; and, consequently, for the general scope and tendency of the work, whatever they may be held to be; the author of the poem is alone responsible. Part the First. If rivers, between green and fragrant banks Flowing, thro' scenes which are a paradise Unto the vision of a soul at peace With its own state and essence; and calm lakes; And murmurous fountains, in recesses dim Far in old forests, where ubiquious life Inhabiteth, in small and myriad forms Astir on every leafâcould, human-voiced, Tell of the human wailings they have heard; Tell of the human writhings they have seen; Tell of the human sighs which with their music, Tell of the human tears which with their waters, Have mingled sorrowing; and the human life That hath exhaled within them, and its clay Left to their liquid keeping; there would sound A never-ceasing utterance in the air, Of mortal wo, and make the ear's fine sense Even a perpetual torture to men's hearts! To know the story of sweet Gunderode, Is to know much of sadness, and that worm Still at the core of things: to know it not, Is to be ignorant of much of grace, Sweetness and love; and thought as delicate As the moist breaking of the springtime buds At Frankfort, in the dwelling of a man By men since crown'd with immortality, If memory be immortal; in the midst Of poets, painters, sculptors and musicians, Statists, and unsurpass'd philosophers; Sat, in her beauty and her innocence, The lady Gunderode. As one in dreams, Continuance of waking visions fed From page of Greek or Roman fabulist, On high Olympus feasteth with the gods; So revell'd Gunderode amid the throng Of those mind-deified men. Amongst them came, Ere it was midnight, one with wine inspired To pluck the rein from off his mettled talk, And let it bound along that verge of thought Which overbrows the dim sea of our dreams: Young was he; with flush'd cheek and vision'd eye, Whence look'd at once the eagle and the dove; His hair o'ertress'd his shoulders; and he wore A vestment such as clad great painters old, Girdled and dagger-fasten'd. Artists, sages, Sat silent as he spake; or were but heard As flowing streams beside a torrent's fall: And Gunderode grew pale and tearful-eyed; And droop'd beneath his beating utteranceâ As doth the casual flower upon a cliff Under the dash of an advanced wave. âI could not,â 'mong a thousand wayward things, Said the intense declaimer eloquent; âNor will I, when the ominous autumn-hour âPlants its first stain upon the green of life, âBear the slow withering in agony, âDown to the dust, of all this pride and grace âOf form and fresh existence. Into death âThese eyes with all their sphered miracle, âOrb within orb of lustre, nothing dimm'd; âThis brow unwrinkled, and these cheeks unfurrow'd âBy the flesh-graving hand of iron Time; âThese lips unblanch'd of their love-kindling blood; âThis flowing hair unstreak'd with sickly grey; âAnd all this active fabric unimpair'd âIn vigor and in symmetry; shall depart, âO' the sudden, from the towers of their perfection âInto the depths of The Invisible; âAnd their full glories vanish utterlyâ âAs at the breaking of a bubble do âThe hues that made it beautiful as heaven. âAnd that fair frame of woman I may love âBeyond the rest of God's developments âOf that Idea whence Creation flow'dâ âLet her, if love from me be life to her, âAnd a possession which she coveteth âTo bear impress'd upon her consciousness, âAt its recession to the Heart of Things; âO, let her not be visible to sense âWhen on her beauty comes the stain of years; âBut glitter from all sight as doth a dewdrop, âWhich now the eye sees on the eglantine, âAnd momently inlidded, sees no more!â O, insolence of life-redundant youth! O, folly of all thought one moment old! O, vanity and danger of wild words! This raver unadvised, this slave of impulse, Died very wrinkled and exceeding grey, On the last verge of man's extremest hour, And smiling peacefully: but so it was not With that pale listener, silent Gunderode. The artists and the sages, at their heart-depths Troubled with stirrings of mortality By that disdainer of man's order'd doom, Yet or philosophised or jested them, Even in the speech-space of a greeting-word, Out of the spiritual presence of their souls: But Gunderode; whose gentle nature yearn'd, With infinite veil'd seekings, toward him Who spake thus idly; as he ceased, arose; And, with a downcast melancholy air, To none directing either word or look, Past from that galaxy of starry minds Unto her distant chamber; musing there, Until the spirit of thought within her shrined Became, like the insect of the lavender, In a strange self-effusion dimm'd and hidden. Part the Second. Of Gunderode Bettine was the friend; The earnest-soul'd and vivid-hearted friend; Dark-eyed, dark-hair'd, mirth-faced and fairy-framed; With a clear voice, that on the pleasured ear Rippled a streamlike music; and a step That kiss'd the ground as lightly as swift wing Of swallow doth the meadow's placid lake, Or insect-sever'd leaf its quiet grass. Bettine's youth was yet i' the early bud When first she knew the lady Gunderode, Who then for two years had in Frankfort been A convent's inmate; a lone canoness; A timid creature, that was wont to tremble But to âsay graceâ aloud; and scarcely dared Greet her prayer-mates with âBenedicite!â Upon the ground her little chamber was; With casement folding-door'd, that open'd out Upon a quiet garden, full of flowers And balmy shrubs and grass-embedded treesâ A miniature of Nature's loveliest scenes! A silver poplar near the window grew; And to its pale boughs would Bettine climb, And from on high read heavenly poesy, Toned ever to the hour and to the scene, Unto the garden's tranced inhabitant; Who sat, or stood, or paced the grass below; One white hand hidden in her bright brown hair, And brow down-bent; or glancing fearfully, As the wind wanton'd where Bettine sat, Up thro' the quivering poplar-leaves. To read Books with a clear and understanding soul Bettine learn'd of thoughtful Gunderode; And from the poesy her genius breathed In worded music drew that subtle lore Which teacheth how to call from every lifecloud A lightning that strikes dead familiar things, And how to revel in that spiritual wonder Which teemeth from their ashes, incense-like. âThat temper of our souls in which we die âOf our Eternity the incipient is! âMuch, much to learn; much with the intellect âTo clasp, and with a passion strong as love's, âAnd deeper far and happier; and then, endâ â'Tis all I crave to do; for not an hour âWould I exist the death's-head of my youth, âMy beauty's posthumous satire!âAh, Bettine; âThe craving wretch who hungers for the Eternal âMust seek it in the untracks of the grave!â âSo, let the Unseen Archer, from his hill âOf awful cloud, select me speedily âFor his unerring arrow. My faint spirit âSwoons in the blaze of things; and all my being âPines in the vacancy of some great want!â In such wise talk'd soul-shadow'd Gunderode Oft to her wondering friend; whose startled mind Trembled with new sensation and new dreams, Self-picturings strange and wild imaginings, For ever, as she spake; and every text Circled with commentation, which at once Show'd ignorance of its meaning, and a knowledge That lent it import deeper than itself; Which still reflective Gunderode enwove Into the mystic texture of her thoughts, Calling it ârevelation.ââThis swift play Of the mind's elemental subtleties Was to the live blood in Bettine's veins As that of tempest-airs to floating cloudsâ Impelling them from north and south and west, Until they choke the sunrise; and its tumult All beat upon her heart, till nigh she drew, In feverous sickness, to the brink of death. New motive and more potent argument For the fulfilment of her calm resolve Drew Gunderode from the sick couch of Bettine: And when, with health replenish'd in her limbs, Blush'd on her cheeks and raying from her eyes, And toning the voice-music of her lips, The pupil sought again her academe, She found its quick preceptress stirr'd and laughing, And ready to let loose all eager thoughts That press'd the barr'd gates of her utterance. âThe busy world,â she said, all mockingly; âThe idle worldâmost idle in its toil, âAnd toiling in its happiest idleness!â âThe foolish world; the ignorant suicide, âThat kills itself with care, and knows it not!â âAnd shuts from suicides its holy graves, âAnd casts them to the highways and the woods, âTo be the fellow dead of helpless creatures âWhich, holding o'er their life no will-throned power, âMust live, howe'er they suffer!âWhat, Bettine, âIs this still ignorantly-censuring world âTo Gunderode?âI have been prating, Dear! âWith a young body-healer; one who deals âWith the grosser parts of man and woman-nature; âWho bloods and physics; plucks frail teeth from the jaw, âAnd yields the eye more after-pain, than present âUnto the part bereaved; who delicately âCuts into human flesh, and human limbs âLops with a grace to shame a posture-master; âWho over a gash'd human carcase revels, âGluttoning on knowledge anatomical; âAnd, with hands buried near his brother's heart, âCensures tired people who will kill themselves âAnd load his learning with another book! âAnd after an ablution, verily, âWill come to me, the living counterpart âOf that dire death-mass which still odors him, â'Spite of pure water and sweet lavender, âAnd angel me with epithets!âGod! Bettine, âThey stagger me with wonder, do these men. âI ask'd of this same death-drag, this deferrerâ â(Save on some odd occasions, when he hastens, âBy scientific accident, the plight âHe's palm-plied to prevent)âI ask'd, I say, âOf this vain wrestler with a doom assured âAnd puny putter-off of striding fate, âWhere sharp death, bodkin'd on a dagger's point, âCould readiest be made inmate of the heart. âHe stared upon me with an ignorant eye, âAnd told meâEven here!ââThe canoness Laid bare her beauteous bosom; and one finger Placed o'er the fountain of its beating life, And criedââHere, here, Bettine!â Silent long, And looking gently in each other's eyes, Stood the death-parted friends; till sobb'd aloud, And fell upon the neck of Gunderode, Her passionate woman-love; implored and wept, And press'd her lips, and kiss'd her throbbing breast Beneath the orbed grace where she had learn' To let the life out from the pained heart: And pale, convulsedâeven as two gleaming lilies, That quail i' the wind together spectrally Far in the faint light of the dying moonâ Thus sway'd they, folded in each other's arms. Beside the casementâthrong'd as unripe thoughts I' the brain of poets, ere they color'd be, And pregnant made, and teeming mightily, By light and heat o' the passions; crowded thickly As feelings new i' the heart of maidenhood, Ere love comes open-eyed and tells it allâ Grew bunches of young grapes, beneath the verdure Of an old vine. These tore Bettine off, And dash'd them on the floor, and trampled them Under her little feet, and cried aloudâ âThus dost thou, Gunderode, tread on my heart, âAnd the fruit crush that swells to ripeness there!â The canoness bow'd down her graceful head, And glanced aside; and paler and more pale Grew momently: when, suddenly, a thoughtâ As a bright creature from the lowest deep Of some transparent pool springs rapidly And flashes a swift splendor into airâ Seem'd to leap wing'd from her profoundest soul Up to her cheeks, there beaming gloriously Awhile; then vanishing as it upsprang, And leaving paleness paler for its coming. And then she rose; and coldest of cold kisses Upon Bettine's brow most icily Imprinted; and a painful silence grew Between them, till they parted: one in tears; And one in calmness too self-wrought for tears. The air which by a dancer's winged heel, Or flitting pinion of aroused bird, Is sunder'd, closeth not again more quickly, With softer motion, or less visible wound, Than did the sorrow-cloven atmosphere Of young Bettine's clear felicity: And the next day she sought the priory, With heart as fresh with joy as morn with dews; And to the chamber of the canoness Went, singing cheerily. A pale attendant Stood weeping at the widely-open door: âThe lady Gunderode is gone,â she said, âUnto the Rheingau; and I pray to God âThat Nature's quiet there may make her spirit âPart of itself.ââBettine could not speak: The nightingale, lone-singing to the stars, Leaves not such silence in the midnight woods At each deep pausing of its melody, As came upon her heart: a solitude, A sense of desolation, and a fear. Part the Third. All Nature worshipp'd with divine Pantheism, As morning o'er the Rheingau smiled, like love On beauty it hath kiss'd to ecstasy: The sky shone full of adoration deep Of the fair river and its willowy banks; Its bordering vineyards, where rich floods of wine Slept in ten thousand fountains; and its flowers, And trees, all vivid in their stainless green, That kindled in the sunlight: and all these Were beaming fond religion to the sky, And to each other: and sweet hymns of birds, And orisons of waters and of winds, Spake praise and joy to all things and in all That shared the bosom of the Universe! Seeming most like some spirit that had charm'd The beauty round her into fairy being, A woman young and perfect-framed and fair Stood in the midst thereof, adoring it With voice and ear and vision; tree and flower, Birds, waters, winds, and all the fervid sky. âBeautiful River! could I flow like thee, âYear after year, thro' this deliciousness âEver-renewing; and retain no more âOf human thought and passion than might yield âA oving consciousness of grace and joy; âI could content me to endure, till Time âHad heap'd such million'd years upon his record, âAs almost in himself to seem and be âThe sole Eternity!âO, trees and flowers; âJoy-throated birds; and ye, soft airs and hues, âThat nestle in yon skiey radiance! âHappy ye are, as beauteous: to your life, âUnrealised, unrealisable, âIntolerable, infinite desire âApproacheth never; and ye live and die, âYour natures all-fulfilling and fulfill'd, âSelf-satiate and perfected.âO, sorrow! âUnto his vagrant, momentary dream, âSay that, obedient to my inmost soul, âOf which his image and his spirit are lords, âI yielded, thought and substance?âFearful God! âAt the first wrinkle's scarce-discerned line âSpanning my brow of youth, from where I stood âThe firm foundations should be cleft away; âLetting me drearily down that abyss âTo which even death's is but as shallowness!â âThose words of his were lightning to my life-pride, âWhich then fell blasted. I accuse them not: âBefore myself but charm'd they my own thought âWith mightiest demoncraft; and, being raised, âTo lay it but remains one sorcery.â âVainly-impassion'd youth and impotent age âAre not a boon; and immortality, âIf color'd, is eclipsed not by the hues, âMore or less deepen'd, of the temporal doom.â âBeautiful River! Verdure and Fragrance sweet! âVoices of waters, winds and living things! âAnd, Skies! whence all this life and light and joy âDescendeth upon allâI leave ye not; âBut come to ye enfranchised from myself, âAnd self-secured from being the jest of time âAnd loathsome vessel of my own decay.â So spake that woman young and beautiful, In the Great Presence; and a sigh was all That again parted her elysian lips. The waters and the willows and fair flowers, And even the splendors of the gracious Arch, Unto the Faculty Divine itself Had at that moment, for a moment's space, Seem'd beautiless and dim; and Glorious Truth, Reveal'd thro' all the Universeâa lie. Sweet Evening brooded on the tranquil Rhine: The flowers all slept; and in the placid sky Were shining tremulous its earliest stars; And in kind Nature's eye no tear was seen, Nor sigh of sorrow heard in her calm voice: Tho' stark and cold upon the river's bank, Under a low-droop'd willow, lay the image Of angels, as they haunt the human soul; With wounded bosom and blood-stained limbs, Strew'd hair, and pallid eyes, and livid cheeksâ A pity, and a withering for the heart! A boat came floating up the quiet Rhine; And earnestly talk'd they who sat thereinâ Save one, a silent and a weeping girl: The boatman moor'd his bark beside the willow; She leapt upon the bank; and on the corse Fell, like another death. Ah! this Our Life Is a moth's twilight-flight, discerned dim In the mysterious air a little while, And then beheld no more: a dreamy cloud Of light and gloom, which melts into the wind Even as we gaze. Weep not for Gunderode! THE DISCORD-HARMONY. She sat with throbbing heart and aching brow, A Discord making wond'rous Harmony! And round her seem'd an atmosphere to flow That made all breathers' eyes melt lovinglyâ Like stars by warm airs lull'd i' the summer sky: And those that listen'd to her glancing fingers Forgot their common life and destiny; And grew enrapt as one lone man who lingers In a dim wood at eve, tranced by its starlight singers. The inward tumult of her breast and brain Lent lightning-swiftness and a thunderous might Unto those gods of music; and the pain Of her surcharged spirit, in despite Of ts dull burthen, gave divine delight With its sublime expression: as are shed Incessant splendors thro' the sombre night, O'er hills and seas, and round us where we tread, From a tempestuous cloud, dense-gather'd overhead. Her hair seem'd struggling from its golden band, As fainer by mad love to be dishevell'dâ Scorning the careful work of her fair hand, Which had in order due its ringlets levell'd; Her forehead in its own fine frownings revell'd, As smoothable by none but love-lip pressure; Her cheeks blush'd at the color that bedevill'd Their god-loved paleness; and her eyes' displeasure, Flashing afar, show'd nought of music's order'd measure. Her lips were motionless; yet on them shook Intensest words fetter'd in silentnessâ As on the still page of a burning book, Whose voiceless oracles than speech express More infinite meaning: her form-fashion'd dress Did heave with the rebellion of her heart, As it would break sweet way for that caress Which love to love still panteth to impart, When Love and Nature make triumphant spoil of Art. And e'en her smooth white hands; whose gifted cunning Made the space vibrate with delicious sound; As anger'd with the task of their swift running, Indignant seem'd o'er all the keys to bound, Reluctant to the spell they wrought around: But, with their passion made more musical, Their loathness in its own excitement drown'd, Their hatred, as their love, gave force to all That onward storm of notes, rolling majestical! TO THE ENGLISH LAIS. Thou with rich balm-breathing lips, Singing us (as weird ones old Did the white and laboring moon Out of her constrain'd eclipse) From that spirit-trancing swoon In which faint who thee behold! Thou with mischief-curved brow, Which who gaze on keep no vow! Thou with basiliskine eye, Which to look in is to die! Thou with hand to tempt a saint; And a bosom which to paint Fancy may, but artist never, Undefeatedly endeavour; And a form love-limb'd, complete, From thy forehead to thy feet: Now reclined, and smoothly still, As made marble by thy will; And now stirr'd to restless motionâ As the zephyr'd boughs of willows, Or the ever-speeding billows Of the wind-excited ocean! Do not tempt me: I retain An Ideal in my brain Thought of thee may never pale; And a Real in my heart O'er which thy caressing art, The sweet beauty of thy face And thy body's perfect grace, Cannot, for an hour, prevail! Lures upon thine eyelids lay; Pout thy lips; and sing; and play, Startling the fine shadows there, With white fingers in thy hair; Or thy practised hand advance Nigh my lip, by sembled chance; Wave thy form along the dance; And, with boundings of thy feet, Make design'd revealments fleet!â These thy daggers strike in vain At my armour'd heart and brain SONNETS. I. THE BURIED BUTTERFLY. What lovely things are dead within the sky, By our corporeal vision undiscern'dâ Extinguish'd suns, that once in glory burn'd; And blighted planets, mouldering gloomily Beyond the girdle of the galaxy; And faded essences, in light inurn'd, Of creatures spiritual, to that Deep return'd From whence they sprang, in far Eternityâ This e'er to know is unto us forbidden; But much thereto concerning may we deem, By inference from fact familiar: Beneath those radiant flowers and bright grass hidden, Withers a thing once golden as a star And seeming unsubstantial as a dream. II. MUSIC AND LOVE. Ah! Music in an atmosphere of Love A portion of the soul of Love becometh; The heard deep-blended with the harmony That is unheard, but to the touch and eye And innermost spirit of sweet life reveal'd: But in an atmosphere of Music, Love Is lost, and wilder'd from the simpleness Of its most silent blissâa murmuring dove, In the dim woods which have its joys conceal'd, By the loud chant of flocking birds invaded; A calm wildflower, that in soft fragrance bloometh, By morn and eve divinely dew'd and shaded, In art's strong perfumes drench'd. Ah! strangely less Doth Love sweet Music serve, than Music Love. III. THE MIST OF FAMILIARITY. In this Eternal, Universal Wonder; Of which we are part, and should percipient be; We move, indifferent, God's Blue Arch underâ By that dull mist, Familiarity, Begirt, and sodden into apathy! Astonishment, nor dread, nor admiration, Nor panting love, nor trembling adoration, Our Life from its lethargic courses waking; Its little self of all things centre making, Tho' need and death its sole circumference!â Even as the Savage Fisherman, when drew Men from far lands, of speech and aspect new, And of strange state, within his scope of view, Fish'd on; nor turn'd his head; nor question'dâWhat? or, Whence? IV. VOLITION. âThe object of volition is not the cause of volition.â âHazlitt. God will'd Creation; but Creation was not The cause of that Almighty Will of God, But that great God's desire of emanation: Beauty of Human Love the object is; But Love's sweet cause lives in the Soul's desire For intellectual, sensual sympathies: Seeing a plain-plumed bird, in whose deep throat We know the richest power of music dwells, We long to hear its linked melodies: Scenting a far-off flower's most sweet perfume, That gives its balm of life to every wind, We crave to mark the beauty of its bloom: But bird nor flower is that Volition's cause; But Music and fine Grace, graven on the Soul, like laws. V. THE âNOLLEKINS.â Ah! Vision fixed and substantialised Of the Old Sculptor's youth!âThe one thing dream'd, Which all his waking life antagonised And from dull Hell his gasping age redeem'd!â Lord! how she clings unto her lover there!â As sentiently and indissoluble As his own veins unto the flesh they wear, When thro' them pants the hot blood voluble!â Oh! In such wondrous god-embracing fashionâ When first the Uncreated Soul Intense Breathed love and life into Primeval Matter, And melted it to form and grace and passionâ Clung the fond Universe to her Creator, And taught Him all the powers of his own Effluence. VI. THE WHEEL OF TIME. The Wheel of Time revolveth restlessly; From morn to night, from night to weary morn: We kindle in the womb, and then are born, And look upon the pauseless world, and cry; And then the ether-light of Infancy Youth flushes with the purple of its morn; And then hot Manhood's noon is soon o'erworn, And Age's eve comes on, and then we die. The old world changes: valley becomes hill, And mountain vale; land sea, and ocean land; And cities deserts, deserts peopled be; The stars are failing, tho' they twinkle still; And nothing in all space doth firmly standâ But round that Mighty Wheel all things whirl ceaselessly. VII. A THOUGHT IN THE PRESENCE OF A DEAD CHILD. The aspect of sweet life; and yet, not life! If thou, dear Child! art dead; and yet dost bear Such vital hues upon thy visage fair; Showing calm living bliss, without the strife Of being's pain and passion, and so rife With sweetness, grace and love, that we not dare To think that death dwells in corruption thereâ How know we, that the clear and gorgeous Vault, With all the light of its star-studded azure, Which to the Eternal doth our thought exalt, Is not, this moment, but one glorious frame That hath the hue of life without the flame; Death at the core of all, and dim erasure Ready to overpall its glory-without-measure? VIII. THE SILENCE. Hush'd Nature, like a sweet soul slumbering, Seems smiling thro her dreams; smiles of calm glory, That can but issue from a dream of God, Her perfect Lover! By that transitory Here-and-there flitting of a ghost of sound, Silence remaineth in her peace profound Inviolate as death; and from the sod The little stir that still is issuing, From busy movements of an atom life, Doth testify of that extreme repose In which such motion is made audible, And heard almost the drooping of the rose Unto its twilight sleep resemblative, And the soft fall of dews invisible. IX. THE HALF-ASLEEP. O, for the mighty 'wakening that aroused The old-time Prophets to their missions high; And to blind Homer's inward sunlike eye Show'd the heart's universe, where he caroused Radiantly; the Fishers poor unhoused, And sent them forth to teach divinity; And made our Milton his great dark defy, To the light of one immortal theme espoused! But half asleep are those now most awake; And, save calm-thoughted Wordsworth, we have none Who for eternity put time at stake, And hold a constant course as doth the sun: We yield but drops, that no deep thirstings slake; And feebly cease ere we have well begun.
